awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Three Case Studies of Natural Disasters
awd_abstract_narration:
Overview

This STS Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant supports archival research to investigate a series of natural disasters that occurred in the Netherlands; one the deadliest floods in European history (the Christmas Flood), rinderpest epidemics that destabilized agriculture, and the arrival of invasive mollusks that jeopardized the entire Dutch coastal defense system. Historical studies thus far consist of case studies highlighting the local and immediate economic effects of individual events. These studies posit no relational connections to these events and offer limited evaluations of their role in the development of Dutch hydro-engineering and medicine. As a result, the impact of these events remains largely provincial and under appreciated. This study will show that these disasters had profound economic, cultural, and environmental implications. The award will support two archival research trips to the Netherlands for collection and analysis of documents pertaining to the historical and spatial dimensions of the proposal plus funding for conference travel to disseminate the results.

Intellectual Merit

The proposed project contends that these events constituted a unique disaster period in Dutch history with significant implications for Dutch society, culture, and environment. It conceives of these seemingly singular disasters as a synergistically connected and ultimately affecting Dutch adaptation resulting in a massive redesign of Dutch water defense and new methods of combating disease. This study is grounded in the methods of historical disaster studies, climate change research, and European historical geography; the researcher has training in environmental history and experience teaching global environmental studies. The final product will argue that these disasters prompted a reordering of the Dutch physical environment, the cultural rationale for understanding risk and calamity, and the place of science and technology in Dutch society. 

Broader Impacts

By tackling issues like the cultural construction of risk and the socio-historical elements of innovation in engineering, the project may have broader significance in risk and hazard research and the history of science and technology; it may provide information relevant to discussions of current natural disasters. In addition, the project will provide opportunities for international education and show the value of cross-cultural understanding, perhaps culminating in a partnership between Dutch and American scholars. The socio-cultural experience of climate change is globally variable which could lead to interesting and provocative discussions between students in the two countries. Whereas flooding, invasive species, and disease are common to both areas, they have very different impacts on culture and engender different responses. Bridging this gap in environmental awareness is one goal of this proposal.

By the eighteenth century, citizens of the United Provinces of the Netherlands knew their society was in decline. No longer a great power of Europe, their political standing and economic influence waned in the face of assurgent European neighbors. To many Dutch observers, the economic and geopolitical troubles of the Dutch Republic were part of a broader decline in the cultural, social, and even moral fabric of their society. The Dutch eighteenth century was also characterized by nature-induced disasters, however. Massive floods dislocated populations destroyed infrastructure, animal panzootics wiped out herds of cattle and disrupted continental trade, and an invasive mollusk threated to undermine the entire coastal water defense system of the Netherlands. This “period of disaster” was traumatic and expensive, but historians have largely ignored their significance in the context of broader Dutch decline. Co-PI Sundberg’s dissertation, entitled “Floods, Worms, and Cattle Plague: Nature-induced Disaster at the Closing of the Dutch Golden Age, 1672-1760” integrated these disasters into the larger historical narrative of Dutch decline and demonstrated the power of disasters to reflect existing anxieties and create new political and economic challenges. Importantly, it also integrated new methods and approaches taken from environmental history, geography and resilience studies, and geospatial history into a field largely dominated by political and economic historians.

 

The environment, this project argued, was a critical actor whose importance transcends historical and disciplinary divisions. A cattle plague pandemic (likely rinderpest) in 1744-1760, for instance, paralyzed regional economies and created new institutional management strategies for disease. This project thus accommodated economic, medical, and political explanations for its virulence. Plague was also responsive to longer-term environmental (particularly climatic) changes, however, that preconditioned its arrival and facilitated its spread. A series of harsh winters, agricultural pests, and river flooding in the early 1740s decimated harvests and depleted stores of fodder. The virus thus entered a particularly fertile territory amendable to its spread.

 

Climate assumes a central role in the periodization of Dutch decline. Rather than focusing on longer-term temperature or precipitation changes, this project builds on recent geographic and historical climatological that investigates the dynamic relationship between societal shocks and climatic variability.  Extreme events like the temperature nadir of 1739-1740, rather than long-term climatic trends, created the conditions that destabilized established coping strategies for stresses like epidemics and flooding. Warmer temperatures also conditioned disasters. In the 1730s, for instance, an invasive marine mollusk called the shipworm (Teredo navalis) was discovered in the wooden revetments that protected Dutch dikes and harbors. The drought conditions of the 1730s created ideal conditions for the introduction and spread of this exotic marine species by limiting the influx of fresh water into the estuaries of the Rhine/Meuse river systems. Environmental changes, and especially climatic changes thus played an integral role in the development and consequences of these disasters.

Using georeferenced historical maps, documentary evidence of shipworm sightings, and historic salinity gradients (isohaline estimates) this project reconstructed the potential extent of shipworm infestations.
